channel.title: NYT > Global Home
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: New Zealand Lawmakers Approve Gay Marriage Bill
item.description: Hundreds of jubilant gay-rights advocates celebrated at New Zealand’s Parliament as the country became the thirteenth in the world and the first in the Asia-Pacific region to legalize same-sex marriage.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Ink: Blast in Bangalore Injures 16
item.description: A bomb planted on a motorcycle exploded near the Bharatiya Janata Party office in Bangalore.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI
item.media:description: Police and forensic officials inspecting the bomb blast site at Malleshwaram in Bangalore, Karnataka on Wednesday.

item.title: Thatcher’s Funeral is Held at St. Paul’s Cathedral
item.description: The ceremonial funeral with military honors for Margaret Thatcher has divided British opinion, much as the former prime minister stirred passions in her lifetime.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: The coffin holding the body of Margaret Thatcher, a former British prime minister, was carried up the steps of St. Paul's Cathedral in London on Wednesday.

item.title: European Auto Market Slump Continues
item.description: New car sales contracted for an 18th consecutive month as demand plunged in Germany and France.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Trial of Russian Activist Aleksei Navalny Is Delayed
item.description: The anticorruption blogger Aleksei A. Navalny is trying to etch a lasting image in the public imagination before his trial on embezzlement charges.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Internet Gun Sites Ease Illegal Sales
item.description: A Times examination found that unlicensed sellers advertise scores of weapons on free classified ads Web sites where people legally barred from gun ownership can buy them.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL LUO, MIKE McINTIRE and GRIFF PALMER
item.media:description: Theresa O’Rourke talked about her friend Jitka Vesel, shown at right in photograph behind her. Ms. Vesel was killed by Dmitry Smirnov, who was stalking her and bought a gun online.

item.title: Physical Legacy of Bomb Blasts Could Be Cruel for Boston Marathon Victims
item.description: Trauma surgeons tried to reach agreement before deciding to amputate a limb, a procedure that was required for many victims of the explosions at the Boston Marathon on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By GINA KOLATA, JERÉ LONGMAN and MARY PILON
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vigil at the Boston Common, near the site of the bomb blasts at the Boston Marathon finish.

item.title: Bomb Details Emerge in Boston Case
item.description: Officials said they were still at the start of an inquiry on the attack at the Boston Marathon that killed three people and hurt more than 170, using what were likely kitchen pressure cookers set up to shoot shrapnel.
item.dc:creator: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, ERIC SCHMITT and SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Mourners attended a vigil for Martin Richard, 8, at a park in Boston.

item.title: Ricin Detected in Letter Sent to Senator Roger Wicker
item.description: An envelope addressed to Senator Roger Wicker of Mississippi showed positive results for the toxin in tests at a mail facility in Washington. It was sent to the F.B.I. for more analysis.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN

item.title: In Grisly Image, a Father Sees His Son
item.description: The family of Jeff Bauman, who lost his legs in the bombings, learned of his fate from an image of the bloodied young man being tended to by a man in a cowboy hat.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ROHAN
item.media:description: Jeff Bauman being wheeled away after the bombing.

item.title: Post-Election Tensions Rise in Venezuela Amid Deadly Protests
item.description: Nicolás Maduro, the newly elected president, and his opponent, Henrique Capriles Radonski, blamed each other for the violence that has killed at least seven people.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Jose Antonio Rivas/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An opposition protest Tuesday in front of an office of the election council in Mérida, Venezuela.

item.title: Whitwell Journal: Thatcher Funeral Does Not Diminish Miners’ Bitterness
item.description: Wednesday’s funeral rites for Margaret Thatcher, the former British prime minister, have become a matter of dispute in Whitwell, where many lost their jobs during the 1980s coal battles.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:credit: Jonathan Player for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neil Wale, a former miner, at the site of what was the Whitwell mine, which closed in 1986.

item.title: Candidate in Paraguay Stirs Controversy With Remarks on Gay Marriage
item.description: Horacio Cartes, the presidential front-runner, compared gay people to “monkeys” and support for same-sex marriage to believing in the “end of the world.”
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Horacio Cartes is the front-runner in the presidential election scheduled for Sunday.

item.title: Museum Review: The New Exploratorium Opens in San Francisco
item.description: The Exploratorium, a science center, opens in a new $220 million building in San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN
item.media:credit: Matthew Millman for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibit dealing with shadows at the Exploratorium.

item.title: Dance Review: ‘The Greatest!,’ Homage to Muhammad Ali, at Gleason’s Gym
item.description: In “The Greatest! Hip Dance Homage to Muhammad Ali,” boxers and b-boys demonstrate their skills in sequences loosely structured around Ali’s life.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN SEIBERT
item.media:credit: Julieta Cervantes for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the sequences loosely structured on the life of Ali, at Gleason’s Gym.

item.title: Rabbit, Duck and Fish Heads Reappear on the Menu in China
item.description: China’s economic boom is driving a culinary revival, as chefs rediscover dishes that haven’t been seen for decades.
item.dc:creator: By CRAIG S. SMITH
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rabbit head in spicy peppercorn sauce at Old Street Rabbit restaurant in Beijing.

item.title: Chávez Heir Charges U.S. Is Behind Unrest Over Vote
item.description: President-elect Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela accused the United States of organizing demonstrations that have led to 7 deaths and 61 injuries during protests against his election.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Engaged in Torture After 9/11, Review Concludes
item.description: “A simple test is to ask what American officials would think if U.S. soldiers or citizens were treated to the same interrogation methods by other nations or armed forces,” writes D in Vancouver.

item.title: Bomb Details Emerge in Boston Case
item.description: “It is a heinous act and I hope that those responsible are captured and tried in a civilian court of law,” writes Jackster in Germany.

item.title: The Lede: Neighbors Mourn Loss of 8-Year-Old
item.description: Bill Richard, the father of the 8-year-old boy who was killed Monday, offered thanks to “our family and friends, those we know and those we have never met, for their thoughts and prayers.”
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON
item.media:description: Martin Richard's father released a statement on Tuesday along with this photo.

item.title: Trial of Russian Activist Aleksei Navalny to Begin
item.description: The anticorruption blogger Aleksei A. Navalny is trying to etch a lasting image in the public imagination before his trial on embezzlement charges begins Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Police officers detained anticorruption blogger Alexei Navalny during a rally in Moscow on Dec. 15, 2012.

item.title: Hospitals Profit From Surgical Errors, Study Finds
item.description: Since insurers pay more for patients with surgical complications, some hospitals could actually lose money by improving care, researchers said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY

item.title: E.U. Carbon System in Doubt as Higher Permit Prices Rejected
item.description: The parliamentary vote places in doubt the future of the European Union’s flagship effort to combat climate change, a system seen as a model by places like China and Australia.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED
item.media:description: A steel plant in IJmuiden, the Netherlands, shown in 2011. Europe's debt crisis has hurt an already ailing carbon emissions trading system.

item.title: Europe Finds Horse DNA in 5% of Tested Beef
item.description: Analyses of more than 7,000 samples turned up horse DNA in about 5 percent of samples and traces of an equine painkiller not approved for human consumption.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: American Airlines Computer Failure Halts Flights
item.description: The airline grounded all of its flights until 5 p.m. Eastern time after experiencing computer problems.
item.dc:creator: By JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: Planes sat on the tarmac at La Guardia Airport after American Airlines flights across the country were grounded.
